awd_titl_txt: NeTs: Small:  Economic Incentives for P2P: Theory and Design
awd_abstract_narration: Although P2P has proven itself as a viable architectural paradigm for distributed applications, the success of future P2P applications ultimately depends on convincing users to volunteer these resources. In this project, two inter-related P2P incentive paradigms are under investigation. In the first paradigm, called Networked Asynchronous Bilateral Trading (NABT), each user has a set of online friends. Users can trade asynchronously with direct friends using local currency and a debt limits. NABT also allows trades to pass through intermediaries. For file sharing, NABT is almost as efficient as a perfect economy, where all users can trade directly with each other. Research is also aimed at extending NABT, developing designs and theories for heterogeneous P2P resource markets.  The second paradigm, called Closed P2P Communities, uses a lightweight centralized banking infrastructure. Here the focus is on designing and analyzing a new class of powerful, but lightweight currency-based incentive schemes.  Game theory is being applied to design incentive mechanisms that optimize deal throughput for diverse P2P markets and pricing theory is used to study the pricing dynamics in closed P2P communities.  Novel approaches for detecting and evicting colluders are also under development. Prototypes for both incentive paradigms will be constructed. The project will provide a framework for a new P2P computing paradigm.  It will involve undergraduate and graduate students, especially minority students. Interactions with industry will be facilitated through the CATT center at NYU-Poly.  Educational material will be developed and disseminated for undergraduate and graduate level networking courses taught by the PIs at NYU-Poly.

por.por_cntn:
Although Peer-to-Peer technology has proven itself as a viable architectural paradigm for a variety of large-scale distributed applications, such as file sharing, video streaming, and digital currency. P2P is far from reaching its full potential. The success of future P2P applications ultimately depends on convincing users to volunteer these resources, which is the challenge of P2P incentive design. In this project, we developed two inter-related new P2P incentive paradigms: Network Asynchronous Bilateral Trading (NABT)}, and Closed P2P Communities. Both paradigms leverage social networks to instill trust into the transactions. We showed that both paradigms provide incentives for peers to participate in a wide range of P2P trading, and achieve a high level of trading efficiency. Both paradigms have a lightweight infrastructure, thereby facilitating large-scale deployment and integration into existing P2P systems. Using cooperative game theory, we designed bidding and pricing mechanisms for peers' video rate selection and adaptation in dynamic video streaming. We theoretically showed that our mechanisms can maximally facilitate and sustain collaboration between peers in dynamic streaming, and peers are truethful and will not collude in bidding for different video versions. We also developed chunk-based P2P streaming algorithms and token-based accounting schemes to implement the proposed incentive mechanisms. Through simulations, we demonstrated that the efficiency of the proposed P2P incentive mechanism and dynamic streaming algorithm.

There are tremendous content available online. It is of great interest for users to quickly identify content of their interests, which is the goal of recommender systems. Social recommender systems utilize similarity and trust between friends to improve the accuracy of content recommendation, which creates opportunities for content exchanges between users within short social distance. We investigated both social-network-traversal based recommendation algorithms, where content of potential interest to a user is identified by traversing his neighborhood in social network, and social collaborative filtering based algorithms, where user and item latent features are extracted by mining user rating data and social trust between friends. We demonstrated that social trust information can significantly improve the accuracy of recommender system. Our proposed Bayesian inference based recommendation is more accurate than the traditional Collaborative Filtering (CF) recommendation and the existing trust based recommendations. In multi-category recommendation, we showed that it is important to identify trust-circle specific for each category, instead of using mixed social trust from all categories. Our proposed trust-circle inference algorithm can further improve the accuracy of the state-of-art social recommender systems. Based on our study of social recommender system, we developed a Facebook app, MVRock, which recommends to users music videos on YouTube to watch, based on the activities and preferences of their Facebook friends.  

 


Last Modified: 10/02/2015
Modified by: Yong Liu
